kalyani_yaman.scale_notation: S R2 G3 M2 P D2 N3 S (Lydian mode)
kalyani_yaman.evidence: Both use Lydian mode with same scale. Kalyani is S R2 G3 M2 P D2 N3 and Yaman uses all shuddh swaras except tivra Ma
kalyani_yaman.notes: Main difference is in movement patterns - Yaman emphasizes Ni Re Ga and Ma Dha Ni phrases, while Kalyani uses Sa Ri Ga Ma Pa Dha Ni movement

shankarabharanam_bilawal.scale_notation: S R2 G3 M1 P D2 N3 S (Major scale/Ionian mode)
shankarabharanam_bilawal.evidence: Shankarabharanam corresponds to Bilaval in Hindustani music and both are equivalent to the Western major scale/Ionian mode
shankarabharanam_bilawal.notes: In Hindustani music, Bilawal is considered the fundamental equivalent

mohanam_bhoopali.scale_notation: S R2 G3 P D2 S (Major pentatonic)
mohanam_bhoopali.evidence: Both are major pentatonic scales using the same five notes
mohanam_bhoopali.notes: Well-established equivalence in Indian classical music literature

hindolam_malkauns.scale_notation: S G1 M1 D1 N1 S (Pentatonic set)
hindolam_malkauns.evidence: Standard equivalents with same pentatonic set
hindolam_malkauns.notes: UPGRADED from mood-equivalent to HIGH equivalence

bhairavi_corrected.scale_notation: Different scales but similar emotional context
bhairavi_corrected.evidence: Hindustani Bhairavi corresponds to Carnatic Thodi in terms of aroha and avaroha
bhairavi_corrected.notes: CORRECTED: Bhairavi ↔ Bhairavi was factually wrong. These are completely different ragas despite sharing the same name

todi_corrected.evidence: Hindustani Todi ≈ Carnatic Shubhapantuvarali, not Miyan ki Todi
todi_corrected.notes: CORRECTED: Todi ↔ Miyan ki Todi was incorrect. They are different ragas
